definitions.definition: To put a load on or in (a means of conveyance or a place of storage).
definitions.example: The dock workers refused to load the ship.

definitions.definition: To place in or on a conveyance or a place of storage.
definitions.example: He loaded his stuff into his storage locker.

definitions.definition: To put a load on something.
definitions.example: The truck was supposed to leave at dawn, but in fact we spent all morning loading.

definitions.definition: To receive a load.
definitions.example: The truck is designed to load easily.

definitions.definition: To be placed into storage or conveyance.
definitions.example: The containers load quickly and easily.

definitions.definition: To fill (a firearm or artillery) with munition.
definitions.example: I pulled the trigger, but nothing happened. I had forgotten to load the gun.

definitions.definition: To insert (an item or items) into an apparatus so as to ready it for operation, such as a reel of film into a camera, sheets of paper into a printer etc.
definitions.example: Now that you've loaded the camera [with film], you're ready to start shooting.

definitions.definition: To fill (an apparatus) with raw material.
definitions.example: The workers loaded the blast furnace with coke and ore.

definitions.definition: To be put into use in an apparatus.
definitions.example: The cartridge was designed to load easily.

definitions.definition: To read (data or a program) from a storage medium into computer memory.
definitions.example: Click OK to load the selected data.

definitions.definition: To transfer from a storage medium into computer memory.
definitions.example: This program takes an age to load.

definitions.definition: To put runners on first, second and third bases
definitions.example: He walks to load the bases.

definitions.definition: To tamper with so as to produce a biased outcome.
definitions.example: The wording of the ballot paper loaded the vote in favour of the Conservative candidate.

definitions.definition: To ask or adapt a question so that it will be more likely to be answered in a certain way.
To encumber with something negative, to place as an encumbrance.
definitions.example: The new owners had loaded the company with debt.

definitions.definition: To provide in abundance.
definitions.example: He loaded carbs into his system before the marathon.

definitions.definition: To weight (a cane, whip, etc.) with lead or similar.
To adulterate or drug.
definitions.example: to load wine

definitions.definition: To magnetize.
Burdened by some heavy load; packed.
definitions.example: Let's leave the TV; the car is loaded already.

definitions.definition: (of a projectile weapon) Having a live round of ammunition in the chamber.
definitions.example: No funny business; this heater's loaded!

definitions.definition: Possessing great wealth.
definitions.example: He sold his business a couple of years ago and is just loaded.

definitions.definition: Drunk.
definitions.example: By the end of the evening, the guests in the club were really loaded.

definitions.definition: Pertaining to a situation where there is a runner at each of the three bases.
definitions.example: It's bottom of the ninth, the bases are loaded and there are two outs.

definitions.definition: (also used figuratively) a die or dice being weighted asymmetrically, and so biased to produce predictable throws.
definitions.example: He was playing with loaded dice and won a fortune.

definitions.definition: (of a question) Designed to produce a predictable answer, or to lay a trap.
definitions.example: That interviewer is tricky; he asks loaded questions.

definitions.definition: (of a word or phrase) Having strong connotations that colour the literal meaning and are likely to provoke an emotional response. Sometimes used loosely to describe a word that simply has many different meanings.
definitions.example: "Ignorant" is a loaded word, often implying lack of intelligence rather than just lack of knowledge.

definitions.definition: (of an item offered for sale, especially an automobile) Equipped with numerous options.
definitions.example: She went all out; her new car is loaded.

definitions.definition: Covered with a topping or toppings.
definitions.example: loaded fries

definitions.definition: Weighted with lead or similar.
definitions.example: a loaded cane or whip
